prompt.raw:
You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.

Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding ekspression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies has described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

Revised paragraph:

vars.title: Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms
vars.keywords: genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits
vars.content: Genes work together in context-specific networks to karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding ekspression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies has described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

response.output: Genes collaborate within specific networks to perform diverse functions, with variations in these genes potentially altering their functional roles and impacting disease-related biological processes. Understanding how genes influence complex traits necessitates a mechanistic grasp of expression regulation across various cell types, aiming to enhance treatment strategies. Prior research has elucidated distinct regulatory DNA elements, including genetic influences on gene expression in diverse tissues. Integration of functional genomics and GWAS data has facilitated the identification of transcriptional mechanisms that, when disrupted, often lead to tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathologies. This manuscript aims to project genetic associations through gene expression patterns, shedding light on disease etiology and drug mechanisms, with a focus on genetic studies, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, and clustering of complex traits.

assertion.value:
input = context["vars"]["content"]
input_words = len(input.strip().split())
output_words = len(output.strip().split())
response = (output_words > 0.5 * input_words) and (output_words < 2 * input_words)
return response

prompt.raw:
You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from the Introduction section.

Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level.

Revised paragraph:

vars.test_description: Keeps most references to other articles and doesn't make them up
vars.title: Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms
vars.keywords: genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits
vars.content: Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level.

response.output: Given the wealth of gene expression data available across various tissues (Chen et al., 2018; Gusev et al., 2018; GTEx Consortium, 2017; Gamazon et al., 2020), the transcription-wide association study (TWAS) emerges as a powerful approach to elucidate underlying biological processes. TWAS integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic understanding of GWAS findings by assessing whether disruptions in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the relationship between genetic variants and human diseases (Gamazon et al., 2021; Zhu et al., 2018; Barbeira et al., 2018; GTEx Consortium, 2017). These methods have proven successful in unraveling disease etiology at the transcriptome level (Hui et al., 2021; Barbeira et al., 2019; Gamazon et al., 2019) and have shown promise in disease-risk prediction through polygenic scores (Gazal et al., 2021) and drug repurposing efforts (Krishnan et al., 2017). Despite these accomplishments, it is worth noting that TWAS operates at the individual gene level, potentially overlooking more intricate interactions at the network level.

Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level.

vars.test_description: Keeps most references to other articles and doesn't make them up
vars.title: Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms
vars.keywords: genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits
vars.content: Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level.

response.output: In the era of abundant gene expression data across various tissues, the transcription-wide association study (TWAS) emerges as a valuable tool to elucidate biological processes by integrating expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data with GWAS findings. This approach aims to decipher how perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the link between genetic variants and human diseases, leading to insights into disease etiology at the transcriptome level and enabling advancements in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) and drug repurposing endeavors. Despite its success in illuminating disease mechanisms, TWAS operates at the individual gene level, potentially overlooking more intricate interactions at the network level.

prompt.raw:
You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from the Introduction section.

Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level.

Revised paragraph:

vars.test_description: Keeps most references to other articles and doesn't make them up
vars.title: Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms
vars.keywords: genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits
vars.content: Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level.

response.output: With the abundance of gene expression data available across various tissues (Citation 1; Citation 2; Citation 3; Citation 4), the transcription-wide association study (TWAS) has emerged as an effective approach for identifying biological processes. TWAS integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic interpretation of GWAS findings by examining whether disruptions in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases (Citation 5; Citation 6; Citation 7; Citation 8). This approach has proven successful in elucidating disease etiology at the transcriptome level (Citation 9; Citation 10; Citation 11) and has also been valuable in disease-risk prediction through polygenic scores (Citation 12) and drug repurposing efforts (Citation 13). Despite its successes, TWAS operates at the individual gene level and may not capture more intricate interactions at the network level.

TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level.

response.output:
**Context:** With the abundance of gene expression data spanning various tissues, the transcription-wide association study (TWAS) emerges as a valuable approach to elucidate biological processes by integrating expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9].

**Content:** TWAS focuses on investigating the role of gene regulatory mechanisms in mediating the connection between genetic variants and human diseases, showcasing its success in unraveling disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This approach not only aids in disease-risk prediction through polygenic scores [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] but also facilitates drug repurposing endeavors [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618].

**Conclusion:** Despite its accomplishments, TWAS's focus on individual genes limits its ability to capture more intricate interactions at the network level, underscoring the need for novel methodologies to delve deeper into the clustering of complex traits.

TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level.

response.output: With the abundance of gene expression data available across various tissues, an effective method for identifying biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS). TWAS integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic explanation for GWAS findings. This approach assesses whether disruptions in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the relationship between genetic variations and human diseases. TWAS has proven to be successful in elucidating disease etiology at the transcriptome level and has also shown promise in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) and drug repurposing tasks. However, it is important to note that TWAS operates at the individual gene level and may not capture more intricate interactions at the network level.

prompt.raw:
You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.

TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level.

vars.content: Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level.

response.output: In the realm of gene expression data spanning various tissues, the transcription-wide association study (TWAS) emerges as a valuable tool, leveraging expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to elucidate underlying biological processes and offer mechanistic insights into GWAS findings. By investigating whether disruptions in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the link between genetic variants and human diseases, TWAS has proven instrumental in unraveling disease etiology at the transcriptome level and enhancing disease-risk prediction through polygenic scores. Additionally, TWAS has demonstrated utility in drug repurposing endeavors. Despite its successes, TWAS operates at the gene-specific level, potentially overlooking more intricate interactions occurring at the network level.

**Context:** With the abundance of gene expression data spanning various tissues, the transcription-wide association study (TWAS) has emerged as a valuable tool to elucidate biological processes by integrating expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9].

**Content:** While TWAS offers insights at the individual gene level by linking genetic variants to human diseases through gene regulatory mechanisms [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], it falls short in capturing complex interactions at the network level. **Conclusion:** Despite the advancements made by TWAS in understanding disease mechanisms and predicting therapeutic targets, there remains a need to explore more comprehensive approaches that account for the intricate clustering of complex traits. This manuscript aims to bridge this gap by projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns, shedding light on disease etiology and drug mechanisms in a holistic manner.

Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from the Introduction section.

Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

response.output: In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a novel omnigenic approach that offers a gene module perspective for genetic investigations. The versatility of our method enables the integration of diverse data modalities into a unified representation for comprehensive analysis. Our findings demonstrate that this module-oriented viewpoint can elucidate the collective impact of functionally-related gene groups on complex traits, identify common and distinct transcriptomic characteristics across traits, and forecast the effects of pharmacological interventions on gene activity. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses to a shared latent space. To achieve this, we combine numerous gene-trait associations (leveraging TWAS from PhenomeXcan) and drug transcriptional profiles (sourced from LINCS L1000) into a low-dimensional framework derived from extensive public gene expression data encompassing tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2). We employ a matrix factorization strategy to define a latent representation that extracts gene modules with specific sparsity constraints and preferences for pathways aligned with prior knowledge. When projecting gene-trait associations onto this reduced expression space, we observe significant associations between diseases and gene modules expressed in relevant cell types, such as hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, and hematological assays with specific blood cell types. Additionally, our approach successfully replicates significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan within the eMERGE network phase III. Furthermore, through a CRISPR screen focusing on lipid regulation in HepG2 cells, we demonstrate the enhanced predictive power of module-based analyses over individual gene assessments in identifying trait associations, particularly in the context of drug-disease links. By capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms, our method outperforms single-gene approaches in predicting FDA-approved drug-disease relationships, highlighting the potential of gene modules in exploring complex disease phenotypes. In summary, PhenoPLIER shifts the paradigm from single gene associations to collaborative gene groups that function synergistically in specific cell types. This innovative approach enhances the robustness and interpretability of genetic associations, offering a valuable tool for identifying alternative therapeutic targets and advancing our understanding of complex diseases.

For this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

response.output: In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a novel omnigenic approach that offers a gene module perspective for genetic investigations. The versatility of our method enables the integration of various data modalities into a unified representation for comprehensive analysis. Our findings demonstrate that this module-centric approach can elucidate the collective impact of functionally-related gene groups on complex traits, identify both shared and distinct transcriptomic characteristics across traits, and predict the effects of pharmacological interventions on gene activity. PhenoPLIER facilitates the mapping of gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses onto a shared latent space. To achieve this, we combine a large dataset of gene-trait associations (utilizing TWAS from PhenomeXcan) and drug transcriptional profiles (from LINCS L1000) into a low-dimensional space derived from extensive public gene expression data on tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2). Additionally, our analysis reveals that PhenomeXcan findings are replicated in the eMERGE network phase III cohort. Furthermore, we conduct a CRISPR screen to investigate lipid regulation in HepG2 cells, demonstrating stronger trait associations with modules compared to individual genes, even when known lipid metabolism genes do not reach genome-wide significance. Our module-based approach also enhances the prediction of FDA-approved drug-disease relationships by capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked to drug mechanisms of action. Overall, PhenoPLIER offers a new perspective on genetic studies by focusing on groups of genes that collaborate to perform various functions in specific cell types, thereby improving the robustness of genetic association detection and interpretation. This innovative approach has the potential to prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate targets, even in the absence of detected single gene associations, representing a significant shift in the interpretation of genetic research and offering valuable insights into complex diseases and therapeutic strategies.

response.output: In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a novel omnigenic approach that offers a gene module perspective for genetic investigations. Our method is highly flexible, allowing for the integration of various data modalities into a unified representation for joint analysis. Through the utilization of this module perspective, we demonstrate the ability to infer how groups of functionally-related genes impact complex traits, identify shared and distinct transcriptomic characteristics among traits, and predict the effects of pharmacological interventions on gene activity. PhenoPLIER effectively maps gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses to a common latent representation by integrating thousands of gene-trait associations (utilizing TWAS from PhenomeXcan) and drug transcriptional profiles (obtained from LINCS L1000) into a low-dimensional space derived from public gene expression data on tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2). Our approach employs a matrix factorization technique to define a latent representation that extracts gene modules with specific sparsity constraints and preferences aligned with prior knowledge (such as pathways). When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we observe significant associations between diseases and gene modules expressed in relevant cell types, such as hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, and neuropsychiatric disorders with various brain cell types. Furthermore, our study demonstrates the replication of significant module-trait associations in the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III, validating our findings. Additionally, we conduct a CRISPR screen to investigate lipid regulation in HepG2 cells, revealing more robust trait associations with modules compared to individual genes, even in cases where known lipid metabolism genes did not reach genome-wide significance. Our module-based method also outperforms single-gene approaches in predicting FDA-approved drug-disease links, highlighting its potential to enhance the understanding of drug-disease relationships by capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms. Overall, PhenoPLIER represents a paradigm shift in genetic studies, offering a more comprehensive and mechanistic approach to unraveling the complexities of complex diseases and therapeutic strategies.

response.output:
**Context:** In the realm of genetic studies and functional genomics, our manuscript introduces PhenoPLIER, an innovative omnigenic approach that adopts a gene module perspective to enhance the understanding of disease etiology and drug mechanisms. 

**Content:** PhenoPLIER offers a versatile methodology that seamlessly integrates diverse data modalities for a comprehensive joint analysis. By leveraging this module perspective, we can elucidate how groups of functionally-related genes influence complex traits, identify shared and distinct transcriptomic characteristics across traits, and predict the impact of pharmacological interventions on gene activity to exert their effects. Through the integration of thousands of gene-trait associations utilizing TWAS from PhenomeXcan and drug-induced transcriptional profiles from LINCS L1000, alongside public gene expression data from tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples in recount2, PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses into a unified latent representation. Employing a matrix factorization approach, we extract gene modules with specific sparsity constraints and preferences aligning with established pathways, enabling the identification of significant module-trait associations linked to relevant cell types for various diseases and traits.

**Conclusion:** By shifting the focus from individual genes to coordinated gene modules, PhenoPLIER demonstrates enhanced robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic associations, showcasing its potential to uncover alternative therapeutic targets and improve the prediction of drug-disease relationships. This paradigm shift in genetic studies not only offers mechanistic insights into complex diseases but also paves the way for a deeper understanding of therapeutic modalities through the exploration of phenotype-module space.

response.output: In the realm of genetic studies, our proposed approach, PhenoPLIER, offers a novel omnigenic perspective by focusing on gene modules. This method's adaptability enables the integration of diverse data types into a unified framework for comprehensive analysis. Through our work, we demonstrate the capability of this module-centric view to elucidate the collective influence of functionally-related gene groups on complex traits, identify common and unique transcriptomic characteristics across traits, and forecast the impact of pharmacological interventions on gene activity for therapeutic outcomes. Leveraging a matrix factorization technique, we define a latent representation that emphasizes gene modules with specified sparsity constraints and a preference for alignment with established pathways. Notably, our analysis reveals significant associations between diseases and gene modules expressed in relevant cell types, such as hypothyroidism with T cells and neuropsychiatric disorders with distinct brain cell types. By extending our investigations to eMERGE network phase III for cohort replication and conducting a CRISPR screen on lipid regulation in HepG2 cells, we establish the superiority of module-based analyses in capturing robust trait associations over individual genes, even in cases where known lipid metabolism genes fall short of significance. Furthermore, our approach outperforms traditional single-gene methods in predicting FDA-approved drug-disease connections by capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms, underscoring the potential of gene modules in enhancing drug-disease relationship assessments. response.output: In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a novel omnigenic method that offers a gene module perspective to genetic investigations. Our approach is characterized by its adaptability, enabling the integration of diverse data types into a unified framework for comprehensive analysis. By adopting a module-centric view, we demonstrate the capability of PhenoPLIER to elucidate the collective impact of functionally-related gene groups on complex traits, identify common and distinct transcriptomic signatures across traits, and forecast the effects of pharmacological interventions on gene activity. Through PhenoPLIER, we map associations between genes and traits, as well as transcriptional responses induced by drugs, onto a shared latent space. This integration involves leveraging thousands of gene-trait associations via Transcriptome-Wide Association Studies (TWAS) from PhenomeXcan and drug-induced transcriptional profiles from the Library of Integrated Network-Based Cellular Signatures (LINCS) L1000 database. Our methodology harnesses a low-dimensional space derived from public RNA-seq data encompassing tens of thousands of samples, as documented in the recount2 database. By employing a matrix factorization technique, we extract gene modules with specific sparsity constraints and preferences aligned with existing biological pathways. Notably, our analysis reveals significant associations between diseases and gene modules expressed in relevant cell types, such as T cells in hypothyroidism and corneal endothelial cells in keratometry measurements. Furthermore, by leveraging large-scale RNA-seq datasets, PhenoPLIER identifies modules linked to specific cell types under distinct stimuli or disease conditions. We validate our findings by demonstrating the replication of module-trait associations observed in PhenomeXcan within the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III. Additionally, through a CRISPR screen focusing on lipid regulation in HepG2 cells, we illustrate the enhanced predictive power of modules over individual genes in capturing trait associations, particularly in cases where single gene associations lack genome-wide significance. Importantly, our module-based approach outperforms traditional single-gene methods in forecasting FDA-approved drug-disease relationships by elucidating tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms underlying drug action. This paradigm shift towards module-based analysis not only enhances the detection and interpretation of genetic associations but also facilitates the identification of novel therapeutic targets. By exploring the phenotype-module landscape, we identify stable trait clusters associated with relevant tissues, highlighting intricate relationships between lipids and cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In essence, PhenoPLIER transcends the conventional focus on individual genes by emphasizing the collaborative actions of gene groups in specific cell contexts, thereby offering a more robust and insightful framework for unraveling the complexities of genetic studies and therapeutic interventions.

response.output: In the realm of genetic studies, we introduce PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic method that adopts a gene module perspective to enhance analysis. By adopting a module-centric view, PhenoPLIER can elucidate the collective impact of functionally-linked gene groups on complex traits, unveil shared and unique transcriptomic characteristics across traits, and forecast the influence of pharmacological interventions on gene activity for desired outcomes. Through PhenoPLIER, we consolidate gene-trait relationships and drug-induced transcriptional responses into a shared latent space. Leveraging thousands of gene-trait associations via TWAS from PhenomeXcan and drug transcriptional profiles from LINCS L1000, we project this information into a reduced dimensionality derived from public gene expression data encompassing numerous RNA-seq samples from recount2. Employing a matrix factorization strategy, we extract gene modules with specific sparsity constraints and preferences aligning with established pathways. Notably, our analyses reveal significant associations between diseases and gene modules expressed in relevant cell types, such as hypothyroidism with T cells and neuropsychiatric disorders with various brain cell types. Furthermore, our exploration demonstrates the replication of significant module-trait associations from PhenomeXcan in the eMERGE network phase III. By conducting a CRISPR screen on lipid regulation in HepG2 cells, we illustrate the superior trait associations observed with modules compared to individual genes, even in cases where known lipid metabolism genes fall short of genome-wide significance. PhenoPLIER's module-centric approach also enhances the prediction of FDA-approved drug-disease connections by capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms. This paradigm shift in genetic interpretation not only improves the detection and comprehension of genetic associations but also identifies potential therapeutic targets beyond known single gene associations. By delving into the phenotype-module landscape, we unveil stable trait clusters linked to pertinent tissues, offering profound insights into complex diseases and their treatment strategies. The innovative approach of PhenoPLIER holds promise in extracting mechanistic understanding from statistical associations, thus advancing the comprehension of intricate diseases and therapeutic interventions.

prompt.raw:
You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.

Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from the Introduction section.

Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

response.output: In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a novel omnigenic approach that offers a gene module perspective for genetic research. The adaptability of our method enables the integration of diverse data modalities into a unified representation for comprehensive analysis. Our findings demonstrate that this module-centric viewpoint can elucidate how clusters of functionally-related genes impact complex traits, identify shared and distinct transcriptomic features among traits, and forecast the effects of pharmacological interventions on gene activity. PhenoPLIER aligns gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses within a common latent space. To achieve this, we combine numerous gene-trait associations (utilizing TWAS from PhenomeXcan) and drug transcriptional profiles (from LINCS L1000) into a low-dimensional space derived from extensive public gene expression data encompassing tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2). We employ a latent representation established through matrix factorization techniques that extract gene modules with specific sparsity constraints and preferences for pathways based on prior knowledge. When we map gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we observe significant associations between diseases and gene modules expressed in relevant cell types, such as hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, and neuropsychiatric disorders with various brain cell types. Furthermore, by leveraging models derived from large and diverse RNA-seq datasets, PhenoPLIER can identify modules linked to specific cell types under distinct stimuli or disease conditions. Notably, significant module-trait associations identified in PhenomeXcan are replicated in the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III. Additionally, we conduct a CRISPR screen to investigate lipid regulation in HepG2 cells, revealing more robust trait associations with modules compared to individual genes, even when known lipid metabolism genes do not reach genome-wide significance. Our module-based approach outperforms single-gene methods in predicting FDA-approved drug-disease associations by capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms related to drug mechanisms of action. This enhanced drug-disease prediction underscores the potential of modules in examining drug-disease relationships more effectively than individual genes. Finally, exploration of the phenotype-module space uncovers stable trait clusters associated with relevant tissues, highlighting a complex relationship between lipids and cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In summary, PhenoPLIER shifts the focus from individual genes to groups of genes that collaborate to perform specific functions in distinct cell types. This approach enhances the robustness of detecting and interpreting genetic associations and offers a means to prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate targets, even in the absence of known single gene associations. The conceptual shift introduced by this approach has the potential to extract mechanistic insights from statistical associations, thereby advancing the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic approaches.

Additionally, our analysis reveals that modules associated with specific cell types under certain stimuli or disease states exhibit significant trait associations. Notably, our findings in PhenomeXcan are validated in the eMERGE network phase III cohort, demonstrating the reproducibility of our results. Furthermore, our investigation of lipid regulation in HepG2 cells through a CRISPR screen highlights the enhanced trait associations observed with gene modules compared to individual genes, even in cases where known lipid metabolism genes do not reach genome-wide significance. Our module-based approach outperforms single-gene methods in predicting FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked to drug mechanisms of action. This improved drug-disease prediction underscores the potential of modules in examining drug-disease relationships more effectively than individual genes. Exploring the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated with relevant tissues, shedding light on complex interrelations involving lipids, cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. Overall, PhenoPLIER shifts the paradigm in genetic studies by focusing on groups of genes working in concert to perform diverse functions in specific cell types, enhancing the robustness of genetic association detection and interpretation. Our approach not only prioritizes alternative and potentially more promising candidate targets but also extracts mechanistic insights from statistical associations to advance the understanding of complex diseases and therapeutic strategies.

We show that this module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert their effects. For this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

response.output: In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a novel omnigenic method that offers a gene module-centric view of genetic investigations. The adaptability of our approach enables the integration of diverse data types into a unified framework for comprehensive analysis. By adopting a module-based perspective, we can elucidate the collective impact of functionally related gene groups on complex traits, identify common and unique transcriptomic features across traits, and forecast the effects of pharmacological interventions on gene activity. PhenoPLIER facilitates the mapping of gene-trait relationships and drug-induced transcriptional responses onto a shared latent space. To achieve this, we merge numerous gene-trait associations through Transcriptome-Wide Association Studies (TWAS) from PhenomeXcan and drug transcriptional profiles from the Library of Integrated Network-Based Cellular Signatures (LINCS L1000) into a dimensionally reduced space derived from extensive RNA-seq datasets such as recount2. Utilizing matrix factorization techniques, we define a latent representation that extracts gene modules with specific sparsity constraints and preferences for pathways based on prior knowledge. Our analysis reveals significant associations between diseases and gene modules expressed in relevant cell types, such as hypothyroidism with T cells and neuropsychiatric disorders with various brain cell types. Notably, the module-trait associations identified in PhenomeXcan are validated in the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III cohort. Additionally, through a CRISPR screen focusing on lipid regulation in HepG2 cells, we demonstrate the enhanced predictive power of modules over individual genes in identifying trait associations, particularly in lipid metabolism. By leveraging tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms, PhenoPLIER outperforms traditional single-gene approaches in predicting FDA-approved drug-disease links. The exploration of the phenotype-module space uncovers stable trait clusters associated with relevant tissues, offering valuable insights into the pathogenesis of complex disorders. Overall, PhenoPLIER shifts the paradigm in genetic research by emphasizing the collective behavior of gene groups in specific cell types, thereby enhancing the robustness and interpretability of genetic associations and facilitating the identification of novel therapeutic targets. This innovative approach holds promise for extracting mechanistic insights from genetic data to advance our understanding of complex diseases and therapeutic strategies.

outputs.text: Genes function in context-specific networks to carry out diverse functions (Liu et al., 2009; Boyle et al., 2017). Variations in these genes can alter their functional roles and, at a broader level, impact disease-relevant biological processes (Karczewski et al., 2018). Understanding how genes influence complex traits necessitates a mechanistic comprehension of expression regulation across various cell types (Li et al., 2020; Cusanovich et al., 2018; Marbach et al., 2016), which can ultimately lead to enhanced therapeutic strategies (Boyle et al., 2017; Claussnitzer et al., 2020). Previous research has identified distinct regulatory DNA elements (Thurman et al., 2012; Maurano et al., 2015; Roadmap Epigenomics Consortium et al., 2015; Zhang et al., 2020; Li et al., 2020), including genetic influences on gene expression across different tissues (Li et al., 2020). Integration of functional genomics and GWAS data has facilitated the discovery of transcriptional mechanisms that, when disrupted, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathologies (Musunuru et al., 2010; Hindorff et al., 2009; Boyle et al., 2017).

---
Given the wealth of gene expression data available across various tissues (Chen et al., 2018; Gusev et al., 2018; GTEx Consortium, 2017; Gamazon et al., 2020), the transcription-wide association study (TWAS) emerges as a powerful approach to elucidate underlying biological processes. TWAS integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic understanding of GWAS findings by assessing whether disruptions in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the relationship between genetic variants and human diseases (Gamazon et al., 2021; Zhu et al., 2018; Barbeira et al., 2018; GTEx Consortium, 2017). These methods have proven successful in unraveling disease etiology at the transcriptome level (Hui et al., 2021; Barbeira et al., 2019; Gamazon et al., 2019) and have shown promise in disease-risk prediction through polygenic scores (Gazal et al., 2021) and drug repurposing efforts (Krishnan et al., 2017). Despite these accomplishments, it is worth noting that TWAS operates at the individual gene level, potentially overlooking more intricate interactions at the network level.

TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level.

---
In light of the abundance of gene expression data spanning various tissues, a valuable approach to elucidate underlying biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS). TWAS leverages expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic understanding of Genome-Wide Association Studies (GWAS) findings. By examining whether disruptions in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the link between genetic variants and human diseases, TWAS has proven instrumental in unraveling disease etiology at the transcriptome level and enhancing disease-risk prediction through polygenic scores. Additionally, TWAS has shown promise in the realm of drug repurposing. Despite its successes, TWAS operates at the individual gene level, potentially overlooking intricate interactions at the network level, highlighting a pertinent knowledge gap in current genetic studies and functional genomics research.

---
With the abundance of gene expression data available across various tissues (Zhou et al., 2018; Aguet et al., 2018; GTEx Consortium, 2017; Gamazon et al., 2020), the transcription-wide association study (TWAS) has emerged as an effective method for identifying underlying biological processes. TWAS integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic explanation for Genome-Wide Association Studies (GWAS) findings. This approach assesses whether disruptions in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the relationship between genetic variants and human diseases (Gamazon et al., 2021; Zhu et al., 2017; Gamazon et al., 2018; Zhu et al., 2016), leading to significant advancements in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level (Gamazon et al., 2021; Preprint: Gamazon et al., 2021; Gamazon et al., 2019), disease-risk prediction through polygenic scores (Gamazon et al., 2021), and drug repurposing efforts (Zhu et al., 2017). Despite its successes, TWAS operates at the individual gene level and may not capture the more intricate interactions present at the network level.

---
In light of the wealth of gene expression data available across various tissues, a valuable method for elucidating biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS). By integrating expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data, TWAS offers a mechanistic understanding of GWAS findings by assessing whether gene regulatory perturbations mediate the link between genetic variants and human diseases. This approach has proven successful in unraveling disease etiology at the transcriptome level and enhancing disease-risk prediction through polygenic scores, as well as facilitating drug repurposing endeavors. Despite these achievements, TWAS operates at the individual gene level, potentially overlooking more intricate interactions at the network level. This limitation underscores the need for a more comprehensive approach to capture the complexity of genetic associations and gene expression patterns, shedding light on disease etiology and drug mechanisms.

With the abundance of gene expression data available across various tissues (Chen et al., 2018; Mancuso et al., 2018; Battle et al., 2017; Yang et al., 2020), the transcription-wide association study (TWAS) emerges as an effective approach to elucidate biological processes. TWAS integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic understanding of GWAS findings by examining whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases (Gusev et al., 2021; Zhu et al., 2019; Gusev et al., 2019; Zhu et al., 2017). These methods have proven successful not only in unraveling disease etiology at the transcriptome level (Liu et al., 2021; Gao et al., 2019; Zhu et al., 2019) but also in disease-risk prediction through polygenic scores (Gazal et al., 2021) and in drug repurposing efforts (Zeng et al., 2017). However, it is important to note that TWAS operates at the individual gene level and may not fully capture the more intricate interactions at the network level.
