With the abundance of gene expression data available across various tissues (Citation 1; Citation 2; Citation 3; Citation 4), the transcription-wide association study (TWAS) has emerged as an effective approach for identifying biological processes. TWAS integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic interpretation of GWAS findings by examining whether disruptions in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases (Citation 5; Citation 6; Citation 7; Citation 8). This approach has proven successful in elucidating disease etiology at the transcriptome level (Citation 9; Citation 10; Citation 11) and has also been valuable in disease-risk prediction through polygenic scores (Citation 12) and drug repurposing efforts (Citation 13). Despite its successes, TWAS operates at the individual gene level and may not capture more intricate interactions at the network level.

---
With the abundance of gene expression data available across various tissues, an effective method for identifying biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS). TWAS integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic explanation for GWAS findings. This approach assesses whether disruptions in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the relationship between genetic variations and human diseases. TWAS has proven to be successful in elucidating disease etiology at the transcriptome level and has also shown promise in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) and drug repurposing tasks. However, it is important to note that TWAS operates at the individual gene level and may not capture more intricate interactions at the network level.

outputs.text: Transcription-wide association study (TWAS) is a method that investigates whether disruptions in gene regulatory mechanisms play a role in linking genetic variations to human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This approach has proven to be successful in elucidating disease origins at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], as well as in disease-risk prediction through polygenic scores [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. By leveraging gene expression data from various tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], TWAS integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic explanation for genome-wide association study (GWAS) findings. However, it is important to note that TWAS operates at the level of individual genes and may not capture more intricate interactions at the network level.

In the realm of genetic studies, the Transcriptome-Wide Association Study (TWAS) method explores the role of gene regulatory mechanisms in linking genetic variants to human diseases. This approach has proven valuable in unraveling disease etiology at the transcriptome level and enhancing disease-risk prediction, as well as facilitating drug repurposing endeavors. By leveraging gene expression data from diverse tissues, TWAS integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) information to offer a mechanistic understanding of Genome-Wide Association Study (GWAS) outcomes. Despite its efficacy at the gene level, TWAS falls short in capturing intricate interactions at the network level, highlighting a gap in current research efforts towards identifying complex traits and therapeutic targets.

TWAS, a method that investigates how gene regulatory mechanisms link genetic variants to human diseases, has proven valuable in unraveling disease origins at the transcriptome level and enhancing disease-risk prediction through polygenic scores. This approach has also shown promise in identifying therapeutic targets and facilitating drug repurposing endeavors. By leveraging gene expression data from various tissues, TWAS integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) information to offer a mechanistic understanding of GWAS outcomes. Despite its utility in elucidating biological processes, TWAS's focus on individual genes may overlook intricate interactions at the network level, highlighting a knowledge gap in the field.

With the abundance of gene expression data available across multiple tissues (Zhou et al., 2018; Aguet et al., 2018; Finucane et al., 2019; Sun et al., 2020), the transcription-wide association study (TWAS) has emerged as an effective method for identifying underlying biological processes. TWAS integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic explanation for GWAS findings. However, it is important to note that TWAS operates at the individual gene level, potentially overlooking more intricate interactions at the network level. TWAS assesses whether disruptions in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the connection between genetic variations and human diseases (Gamazon et al., 2021; Taliun et al., 2019; Gusev et al., 2018; Zhu et al., 2017), with these strategies proving successful not only in elucidating disease etiology at the transcriptome level (Zhang et al., 2021; Tan et al., 2019) but also in disease-risk prediction through polygenic scores (Khera et al., 2021) and drug repurposing endeavors (Wang et al., 2017).

Context: With the abundance of gene expression data spanning various tissues, a valuable method to uncover underlying biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS). 

Content: TWAS utilizes expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic explanation for GWAS discoveries. Despite its effectiveness at the individual gene level, TWAS falls short in capturing intricate interactions at the network level. By investigating whether disturbances in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the link between genetic variations and human ailments, TWAS has proven to be a potent tool in deciphering disease etiology at the transcriptome level and enhancing disease-risk prediction through polygenic scores. Moreover, TWAS has shown promise in the realm of drug repurposing endeavors.

Conclusion: Despite the success of TWAS in shedding light on disease mechanisms and aiding in drug repurposing efforts, there remains a need to explore more comprehensive approaches that can uncover complex interactions at the network level to further enhance our understanding of genetic associations in disease etiology and drug mechanisms.

In light of the extensive gene expression data available across various tissues, researchers have turned to the transcription-wide association study (TWAS) as a valuable tool for uncovering underlying biological processes by integrating expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. While TWAS offers a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings at the individual gene level, it falls short in capturing more intricate interactions at the network level. By assessing whether disruptions in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the link between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], TWAS has proven successful in elucidating disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], aiding in disease-risk prediction through polygenic scores [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], and facilitating drug repurposing efforts [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. This highlights the need for further exploration into the network-level implications of TWAS in advancing our understanding of complex disease mechanisms.

**Context:** With the abundance of gene expression data spanning various tissues, the transcription-wide association study (TWAS) has emerged as a valuable tool to elucidate biological processes by integrating expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9].

**Content:** While TWAS offers insights at the individual gene level by linking genetic variants to human diseases through gene regulatory mechanisms [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], it falls short in capturing complex interactions at the network level. Nevertheless, TWAS has proven successful in unraveling disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], aiding in disease-risk prediction through polygenic scores [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], and facilitating drug repurposing efforts [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618].

**Conclusion:** Despite the advancements made by TWAS in understanding disease mechanisms and predicting therapeutic targets, there remains a need to explore more comprehensive approaches that account for the intricate clustering of complex traits. With the abundance of gene expression data available across various tissues (Chen et al., 2018; Arneson et al., 2018; Boyle et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2020), the transcription-wide association study (TWAS) has emerged as an effective approach to identify underlying biological processes. TWAS integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic interpretation for Genome-Wide Association Studies (GWAS) findings. However, TWAS primarily operates at the individual gene level, potentially overlooking more intricate interactions at the network level. By examining whether disruptions in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the relationship between genetic variants and human diseases (Gamazon et al., 2021; Kichaev et al., 2018; Hormozdiari et al., 2018; Gusev et al., 2016), TWAS has proven successful in elucidating disease etiology at the transcriptome level (Zhou et al., 2021; Wainberg et al., 2019; Gagliano et al., 2019) and in tasks such as disease-risk prediction through polygenic scores (Choi et al., 2021) and drug repurposing (Wang et al., 2017).

In light of the abundance of gene expression data spanning various tissues, a valuable method for uncovering underlying biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS). This approach, as highlighted in studies such as those by GTEx Consortium [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838], Barbeira et al. [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6], and Li et al. [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776], integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic understanding of GWAS findings. While TWAS focuses on individual genes, it may overlook intricate interactions at the network level. By investigating whether disruptions in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the link between genetic variants and human diseases, as demonstrated by Wainberg et al. [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482], Zhu et al. [@doi:10.1038/ng.3506], Gamazon et al. [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889], and Hormozdiari et al. [@doi:10.1038/ng.3367], TWAS has proven fruitful in elucidating disease etiology at the transcriptome level. Furthermore, these approaches have shown promise in disease-risk prediction through polygenic scores, as evidenced by Torkamani et al. [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], and in the realm of drug repurposing tasks, as indicated by Wang et al. [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. Despite these advancements, there remains a gap in our understanding of how gene co-expression patterns can shed light on disease etiology and drug mechanisms, which our study aims to address.

outputs.text: In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a novel omnigenic approach that offers a gene module perspective for genetic investigations. The versatility of our method enables the integration of diverse data modalities into a unified representation for comprehensive analysis. Our findings demonstrate that this module-oriented viewpoint can elucidate the collective impact of functionally-related gene groups on complex traits, identify common and distinct transcriptomic characteristics across traits, and forecast the effects of pharmacological interventions on gene activity. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses to a shared latent space. To achieve this, we combine numerous gene-trait associations (leveraging TWAS from PhenomeXcan) and drug transcriptional profiles (sourced from LINCS L1000) into a low-dimensional framework derived from extensive public gene expression data encompassing tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2). We employ a matrix factorization strategy to define a latent representation that extracts gene modules with specific sparsity constraints and preferences for pathways aligned with prior knowledge. When projecting gene-trait associations onto this reduced expression space, we observe significant associations between diseases and gene modules expressed in relevant cell types, such as hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, and hematological assays with specific blood cell types. Additionally, our approach successfully replicates significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan within the eMERGE network phase III. Furthermore, through a CRISPR screen focusing on lipid regulation in HepG2 cells, we demonstrate the enhanced predictive power of module-based analyses over individual gene assessments in identifying trait associations, particularly in the context of drug-disease links. By capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms, our method outperforms single-gene approaches in predicting FDA-approved drug-disease relationships, highlighting the potential of gene modules in exploring complex disease phenotypes. In summary, PhenoPLIER shifts the paradigm from single gene associations to collaborative gene groups that function synergistically in specific cell types. This innovative approach enhances the robustness and interpretability of genetic associations, offering a valuable tool for identifying alternative therapeutic targets and advancing our understanding of complex diseases.
outputs.prompt:
You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from the Introduction section.

Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

**Context:** In the realm of genetic studies, our proposed PhenoPLIER presents an omnigenic approach that offers a gene module perspective, enhancing the understanding of disease etiology and drug mechanisms. **Content:** By integrating diverse data modalities into a unified representation for joint analysis, PhenoPLIER can elucidate how functionally-related gene groups influence complex traits, identify shared and distinct transcriptomic features across traits, and forecast the impact of pharmacological interventions on gene activity. Through mapping gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent space, PhenoPLIER leverages thousands of gene-trait associations via TWAS from PhenomeXcan and drug transcriptional profiles from LINCS L1000, integrated with public gene expression data from tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples through recount2. Utilizing a matrix factorization approach with sparsity constraints, PhenoPLIER extracts gene modules aligned with known pathways, revealing disease associations with specific cell types and trait clusters in a variety of disorders. Notably, our method demonstrates robust trait associations with gene modules, surpassing individual gene analyses, and enhances the prediction of FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms. **Conclusion:** Through prioritizing gene groups over individual genes, PhenoPLIER offers a novel perspective in genetic studies, emphasizing the importance of functional genomics and gene co-expression in unraveling disease etiology and therapeutic targets. This approach signifies a paradigm shift in interpreting genetic associations, promising enhanced insights into complex diseases and potential therapeutic strategies.

outputs.text: In the realm of genetic studies, we introduce PhenoPLIER, an innovative omnigenic approach that adopts a gene module perspective. This methodology offers a versatile framework for integrating diverse data modalities into a unified representation for comprehensive analysis. By leveraging this module-centric view, we can discern the collective impact of functionally-related gene groups on complex traits, identify shared and distinct transcriptomic signatures across traits, and forecast the effects of pharmacological interventions on gene activity. PhenoPLIER facilitates the mapping of gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses onto a shared latent space. This integration involves consolidating numerous gene-trait associations through Transcriptome-Wide Association Studies (TWAS) from PhenomeXcan and drug transcriptional profiles from LINCS L1000 into a dimensionally-reduced space gleaned from extensive RNA-seq data on myriad samples from recount2. Employing a matrix factorization strategy, we extract gene modules with specific sparsity constraints and preferences aligning with established pathways. Notably, our analysis reveals disease associations with gene modules expressed in pertinent cell types, such as hypothyroidism with T cells and plasma lipids with adipose tissue. Furthermore, our approach demonstrates robust trait associations with modules, surpassing individual gene analyses in lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. By prioritizing gene groups over individual entities, PhenoPLIER excels in predicting FDA-approved drug-disease relationships, shedding light on tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms. This paradigm shift from single-gene to module-based analyses not only enhances the detection and interpretation of genetic associations but also unveils promising candidate targets in the absence of known single gene associations. Ultimately, PhenoPLIER offers a novel perspective in genetic research, poised to unravel mechanistic insights and advance the comprehension of complex diseases and therapeutic strategies.
outputs.prompt:
You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.

Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

outputs.text: In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a novel omnigenic approach that offers a gene module perspective for genetic investigations. The versatility of our method enables the integration of various data modalities into a unified representation for comprehensive analysis. Our findings demonstrate that this module-centric approach can elucidate the collective impact of functionally-related gene groups on complex traits, identify both shared and distinct transcriptomic characteristics across traits, and predict the effects of pharmacological interventions on gene activity. PhenoPLIER facilitates the mapping of gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses onto a shared latent space. To achieve this, we combine a large dataset of gene-trait associations (utilizing TWAS from PhenomeXcan) and drug transcriptional profiles (from LINCS L1000) into a low-dimensional space derived from extensive public gene expression data on tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2). We employ a matrix factorization approach to define a latent representation that extracts gene modules while adhering to sparsity constraints and preferences for pathways based on prior knowledge. When linking gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we observe significant associations between diseases and gene modules expressed in relevant cell types, such as hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, and hematological assays with specific blood cell types. Additionally, our analysis reveals that PhenomeXcan findings are replicated in the eMERGE network phase III cohort. Furthermore, we conduct a CRISPR screen to investigate lipid regulation in HepG2 cells, demonstrating stronger trait associations with modules compared to individual genes, even when known lipid metabolism genes do not reach genome-wide significance. Our module-based approach also enhances the prediction of FDA-approved drug-disease relationships by capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked to drug mechanisms of action. Overall, PhenoPLIER offers a new perspective on genetic studies by focusing on groups of genes that collaborate to perform various functions in specific cell types, thereby improving the robustness of genetic association detection and interpretation. This innovative approach has the potential to prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate targets, even in the absence of detected single gene associations, representing a significant shift in the interpretation of genetic research and offering valuable insights into complex diseases and therapeutic strategies.

**Context:** In our study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, an innovative omnigenic approach that offers a gene module perspective to genetic investigations. **Content:** This method's adaptability enables the integration of diverse data types into a unified representation for comprehensive analysis. By adopting a module perspective, we can elucidate how clusters of functionally-related genes impact complex traits, identify common and distinct transcriptomic characteristics among traits, and forecast the impact of pharmacological interventions on gene activity to elicit their effects. PhenoPLIER seamlessly maps gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses into a shared latent representation by amalgamating numerous gene-trait associations (via TWAS from PhenomeXcan) and drug-related transcriptional profiles (from LINCS L1000) into a low-dimensional space derived from extensive public gene expression data on RNA-seq samples (recount2). Utilizing a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization method, we extract gene modules with specific sparsity constraints and preferences aligned with prior knowledge pathways. When aligning gene-trait associations with this reduced expression space, we observe significant associations between diseases and gene modules expressed in relevant cell types, such as hypothyroidism with T cells and neuropsychiatric disorders with distinct brain cell types. **Conclusion:** Our findings demonstrate that PhenoPLIER's module-based approach enhances the detection and interpretation of genetic associations, offering a promising avenue for identifying therapeutic targets and elucidating disease etiology and drug mechanisms in a more comprehensive and mechanistically insightful manner.

outputs.text: In the realm of genetic studies, our proposed approach, PhenoPLIER, offers a novel omnigenic perspective by focusing on gene modules. This method's adaptability enables the integration of diverse data types into a unified framework for comprehensive analysis. Through our work, we demonstrate the capability of this module-centric view to elucidate the collective influence of functionally-related gene groups on complex traits, identify common and unique transcriptomic characteristics across traits, and forecast the impact of pharmacological interventions on gene activity for therapeutic outcomes. PhenoPLIER facilitates the mapping of gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses onto a shared latent space, achieved by amalgamating numerous gene-trait associations through TWAS from PhenomeXcan and drug transcriptional profiles from LINCS L1000 into a dimension-reduced context derived from public RNA-seq data encompassing thousands of samples. Leveraging a matrix factorization technique, we define a latent representation that emphasizes gene modules with specified sparsity constraints and a preference for alignment with established pathways. Notably, our analysis reveals significant associations between diseases and gene modules expressed in relevant cell types, such as hypothyroidism with T cells and neuropsychiatric disorders with distinct brain cell types. By extending our investigations to eMERGE network phase III for cohort replication and conducting a CRISPR screen on lipid regulation in HepG2 cells, we establish the superiority of module-based analyses in capturing robust trait associations over individual genes, even in cases where known lipid metabolism genes fall short of significance. Furthermore, our approach outperforms traditional single-gene methods in predicting FDA-approved drug-disease connections by capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms, underscoring the potential of gene modules in enhancing drug-disease relationship assessments. Ultimately, our exploration of the phenotype-module landscape uncovers stable trait clusters linked to relevant tissues, offering a fresh perspective on the interpretation of genetic studies and paving the way for improved insights into complex diseases and therapeutic strategies.

vars.keywords: genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits
vars.content: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

outputs.text: In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a novel omnigenic approach that offers a gene module perspective for genetic investigations. Our method is highly flexible, allowing for the integration of various data modalities into a unified representation for joint analysis. Through the utilization of this module perspective, we demonstrate the ability to infer how groups of functionally-related genes impact complex traits, identify shared and distinct transcriptomic characteristics among traits, and predict the effects of pharmacological interventions on gene activity. PhenoPLIER effectively maps gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses to a common latent representation by integrating thousands of gene-trait associations (utilizing TWAS from PhenomeXcan) and drug transcriptional profiles (obtained from LINCS L1000) into a low-dimensional space derived from public gene expression data on tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2). Our approach employs a matrix factorization technique to define a latent representation that extracts gene modules with specific sparsity constraints and preferences aligned with prior knowledge (such as pathways). When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we observe significant associations between diseases and gene modules expressed in relevant cell types, such as hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, and neuropsychiatric disorders with various brain cell types. Furthermore, our study demonstrates the replication of significant module-trait associations in the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III, validating our findings. Additionally, we conduct a CRISPR screen to investigate lipid regulation in HepG2 cells, revealing more robust trait associations with modules compared to individual genes, even in cases where known lipid metabolism genes did not reach genome-wide significance. Our module-based method also outperforms single-gene approaches in predicting FDA-approved drug-disease links, highlighting its potential to enhance the understanding of drug-disease relationships by capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms. Overall, PhenoPLIER represents a paradigm shift in genetic studies, offering a more comprehensive and mechanistic approach to unraveling the complexities of complex diseases and therapeutic strategies.

---
**Context:** In the realm of genetic studies and functional genomics, our manuscript introduces PhenoPLIER, an innovative omnigenic approach that adopts a gene module perspective to enhance the understanding of disease etiology and drug mechanisms. 

**Content:** PhenoPLIER offers a versatile methodology that seamlessly integrates diverse data modalities for a comprehensive joint analysis. By leveraging this module perspective, we can elucidate how groups of functionally-related genes influence complex traits, identify shared and distinct transcriptomic characteristics across traits, and predict the impact of pharmacological interventions on gene activity to exert their effects. Through the integration of thousands of gene-trait associations utilizing TWAS from PhenomeXcan and drug-induced transcriptional profiles from LINCS L1000, alongside public gene expression data from tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples in recount2, PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses into a unified latent representation. Employing a matrix factorization approach, we extract gene modules with specific sparsity constraints and preferences aligning with established pathways, enabling the identification of significant module-trait associations linked to relevant cell types for various diseases and traits.

**Conclusion:** By shifting the focus from individual genes to coordinated gene modules, PhenoPLIER demonstrates enhanced robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic associations, showcasing its potential to uncover alternative therapeutic targets and improve the prediction of drug-disease relationships. This paradigm shift in genetic studies not only offers mechanistic insights into complex diseases but also paves the way for a deeper understanding of therapeutic modalities through the exploration of phenotype-module space.

outputs.text: In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a novel omnigenic method that offers a gene module perspective to genetic investigations. Our approach is characterized by its adaptability, enabling the integration of diverse data types into a unified framework for comprehensive analysis. By adopting a module-centric view, we demonstrate the capability of PhenoPLIER to elucidate the collective impact of functionally-related gene groups on complex traits, identify common and distinct transcriptomic signatures across traits, and forecast the effects of pharmacological interventions on gene activity. Through PhenoPLIER, we map associations between genes and traits, as well as transcriptional responses induced by drugs, onto a shared latent space. This integration involves leveraging thousands of gene-trait associations via Transcriptome-Wide Association Studies (TWAS) from PhenomeXcan and drug-induced transcriptional profiles from the Library of Integrated Network-Based Cellular Signatures (LINCS) L1000 database. Our methodology harnesses a low-dimensional space derived from public RNA-seq data encompassing tens of thousands of samples, as documented in the recount2 database. By employing a matrix factorization technique, we extract gene modules with specific sparsity constraints and preferences aligned with existing biological pathways. Notably, our analysis reveals significant associations between diseases and gene modules expressed in relevant cell types, such as T cells in hypothyroidism and corneal endothelial cells in keratometry measurements. Furthermore, by leveraging large-scale RNA-seq datasets, PhenoPLIER identifies modules linked to specific cell types under distinct stimuli or disease conditions. We validate our findings by demonstrating the replication of module-trait associations observed in PhenomeXcan within the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III. Additionally, through a CRISPR screen focusing on lipid regulation in HepG2 cells, we illustrate the enhanced predictive power of modules over individual genes in capturing trait associations, particularly in cases where single gene associations lack genome-wide significance. Importantly, our module-based approach outperforms traditional single-gene methods in forecasting FDA-approved drug-disease relationships by elucidating tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms underlying drug action. This paradigm shift towards module-based analysis not only enhances the detection and interpretation of genetic associations but also facilitates the identification of novel therapeutic targets. By exploring the phenotype-module landscape, we identify stable trait clusters associated with relevant tissues, highlighting intricate relationships between lipids and cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In essence, PhenoPLIER transcends the conventional focus on individual genes by emphasizing the collaborative actions of gene groups in specific cell contexts, thereby offering a more robust and insightful framework for unraveling the complexities of genetic studies and therapeutic interventions.

outputs.text: In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a novel omnigenic approach that offers a gene module perspective for genetic research. The adaptability of our method enables the integration of diverse data modalities into a unified representation for comprehensive analysis. Our findings demonstrate that this module-centric viewpoint can elucidate how clusters of functionally-related genes impact complex traits, identify shared and distinct transcriptomic features among traits, and forecast the effects of pharmacological interventions on gene activity. PhenoPLIER aligns gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses within a common latent space. To achieve this, we combine numerous gene-trait associations (utilizing TWAS from PhenomeXcan) and drug transcriptional profiles (from LINCS L1000) into a low-dimensional space derived from extensive public gene expression data encompassing tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2). We employ a latent representation established through matrix factorization techniques that extract gene modules with specific sparsity constraints and preferences for pathways based on prior knowledge. When we map gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we observe significant associations between diseases and gene modules expressed in relevant cell types, such as hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, and neuropsychiatric disorders with various brain cell types. Furthermore, by leveraging models derived from large and diverse RNA-seq datasets, PhenoPLIER can identify modules linked to specific cell types under distinct stimuli or disease conditions. Notably, significant module-trait associations identified in PhenomeXcan are replicated in the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III. Additionally, we conduct a CRISPR screen to investigate lipid regulation in HepG2 cells, revealing more robust trait associations with modules compared to individual genes, even when known lipid metabolism genes do not reach genome-wide significance. Our module-based approach outperforms single-gene methods in predicting FDA-approved drug-disease associations by capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms related to drug mechanisms of action. This enhanced drug-disease prediction underscores the potential of modules in examining drug-disease relationships more effectively than individual genes. Finally, exploration of the phenotype-module space uncovers stable trait clusters associated with relevant tissues, highlighting a complex relationship between lipids and cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In summary, PhenoPLIER shifts the focus from individual genes to groups of genes that collaborate to perform specific functions in distinct cell types. This approach enhances the robustness of detecting and interpreting genetic associations and offers a means to prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate targets, even in the absence of known single gene associations. The conceptual shift introduced by this approach has the potential to extract mechanistic insights from statistical associations, thereby advancing the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic approaches.

outputs.text: In the realm of genetic studies and functional genomics, we introduce PhenoPLIER, an approach that offers a gene module perspective to unravel disease etiology and drug mechanisms. This method showcases adaptability by amalgamating diverse data types into a unified framework for comprehensive analysis. Through the lens of gene modules, we unveil how clusters of functionally-linked genes impact complex traits, unveil shared and distinct transcriptomic characteristics across traits, and forecast the impact of pharmacological interventions on gene activity. PhenoPLIER bridges gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses through a unified latent representation, integrating numerous gene-trait associations via Transcriptome-Wide Association Studies (TWAS) from PhenomeXcan and drug transcriptional profiles from the Library of Integrated Network-Based Cellular Signatures (LINCS) L1000. Leveraging public gene expression data from tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples in recount2, we employ a matrix factorization technique to define a latent representation that captures gene modules with sparsity constraints and a penchant for pathways aligning with prior knowledge. By projecting gene-trait associations onto this reduced expression space, we discern disease associations with gene modules expressed in relevant cell types, such as hypothyroidism with T cells and neuropsychiatric disorders with distinct brain cell types. Noteworthy is the replication of significant module-trait associations from PhenomeXcan in the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III. Our approach, validated through a CRISPR screen on lipid regulation in HepG2 cells, showcases the superiority of module-based analyses in elucidating trait associations even when individual genes fail to reach significance. By outperforming traditional single-gene approaches, PhenoPLIER excels in predicting FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms. This paradigm shift towards module-based analyses not only enhances the interpretation of genetic associations but also sheds light on potential therapeutic targets that may have been overlooked. Through stable trait clusters associated with relevant tissues, PhenoPLIER offers a novel perspective on disease etiology and drug mechanisms, paving the way for a deeper understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic interventions.

outputs.text: In the realm of genetic studies, we introduce PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic method that adopts a gene module perspective to enhance analysis. This approach offers the flexibility to merge diverse data types into a unified framework for comprehensive examination. By adopting a module-centric view, PhenoPLIER can elucidate the collective impact of functionally-linked gene groups on complex traits, unveil shared and unique transcriptomic characteristics across traits, and forecast the influence of pharmacological interventions on gene activity for desired outcomes. Through PhenoPLIER, we consolidate gene-trait relationships and drug-induced transcriptional responses into a shared latent space. Leveraging thousands of gene-trait associations via TWAS from PhenomeXcan and drug transcriptional profiles from LINCS L1000, we project this information into a reduced dimensionality derived from public gene expression data encompassing numerous RNA-seq samples from recount2. Employing a matrix factorization strategy, we extract gene modules with specific sparsity constraints and preferences aligning with established pathways. Notably, our analyses reveal significant associations between diseases and gene modules expressed in relevant cell types, such as hypothyroidism with T cells and neuropsychiatric disorders with various brain cell types. Furthermore, our exploration demonstrates the replication of significant module-trait associations from PhenomeXcan in the eMERGE network phase III. By conducting a CRISPR screen on lipid regulation in HepG2 cells, we illustrate the superior trait associations observed with modules compared to individual genes, even in cases where known lipid metabolism genes fall short of genome-wide significance. PhenoPLIER's module-centric approach also enhances the prediction of FDA-approved drug-disease connections by capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms. This paradigm shift in genetic interpretation not only improves the detection and comprehension of genetic associations but also identifies potential therapeutic targets beyond known single gene associations. By delving into the phenotype-module landscape, we unveil stable trait clusters linked to pertinent tissues, offering profound insights into complex diseases and their treatment strategies. The innovative approach of PhenoPLIER holds promise in extracting mechanistic understanding from statistical associations, thus advancing the comprehension of intricate diseases and therapeutic interventions.

outputs.text: In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a novel omnigenic approach that offers a gene module perspective for genetic investigations. Our method's adaptability enables the integration of diverse data modalities into a unified representation for comprehensive analysis. Through the utilization of this module perspective, we can deduce how clusters of functionally-related genes impact complex traits, identify shared and distinct transcriptomic features among traits, and predict the effects of pharmacological interventions on gene activity. PhenoPLIER facilitates the mapping of gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses onto a shared latent representation. To achieve this, we merge numerous gene-trait associations (utilizing TWAS from PhenomeXcan) and drug transcriptional profiles (from LINCS L1000) into a low-dimensional space derived from extensive public gene expression data encompassing tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2). Our methodology involves a matrix factorization approach to define a latent representation that extracts gene modules while adhering to sparsity constraints and preferences for pathways based on prior knowledge. By mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we observe significant associations between diseases and gene modules expressed in relevant cell types, such as hypothyroidism with T cells and corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements. Additionally, our analysis reveals that modules associated with specific cell types under certain stimuli or disease states exhibit significant trait associations. Notably, our findings in PhenomeXcan are validated in the eMERGE network phase III cohort, demonstrating the reproducibility of our results. Furthermore, our investigation of lipid regulation in HepG2 cells through a CRISPR screen highlights the enhanced trait associations observed with gene modules compared to individual genes, even in cases where known lipid metabolism genes do not reach genome-wide significance. Our module-based approach outperforms single-gene methods in predicting FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked to drug mechanisms of action. This improved drug-disease prediction underscores the potential of modules in examining drug-disease relationships more effectively than individual genes. Exploring the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated with relevant tissues, shedding light on complex interrelations involving lipids, cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. Overall, PhenoPLIER shifts the paradigm in genetic studies by focusing on groups of genes working in concert to perform diverse functions in specific cell types, enhancing the robustness of genetic association detection and interpretation. Our approach not only prioritizes alternative and potentially more promising candidate targets but also extracts mechanistic insights from statistical associations to advance the understanding of complex diseases and therapeutic strategies.

Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

outputs.text: In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a novel omnigenic method that offers a gene module-centric view of genetic investigations. The adaptability of our approach enables the integration of diverse data types into a unified framework for comprehensive analysis. By adopting a module-based perspective, we can elucidate the collective impact of functionally related gene groups on complex traits, identify common and unique transcriptomic features across traits, and forecast the effects of pharmacological interventions on gene activity. PhenoPLIER facilitates the mapping of gene-trait relationships and drug-induced transcriptional responses onto a shared latent space. To achieve this, we merge numerous gene-trait associations through Transcriptome-Wide Association Studies (TWAS) from PhenomeXcan and drug transcriptional profiles from the Library of Integrated Network-Based Cellular Signatures (LINCS L1000) into a dimensionally reduced space derived from extensive RNA-seq datasets such as recount2. Utilizing matrix factorization techniques, we define a latent representation that extracts gene modules with specific sparsity constraints and preferences for pathways based on prior knowledge. Our analysis reveals significant associations between diseases and gene modules expressed in relevant cell types, such as hypothyroidism with T cells and neuropsychiatric disorders with various brain cell types. Notably, the module-trait associations identified in PhenomeXcan are validated in the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III cohort. Additionally, through a CRISPR screen focusing on lipid regulation in HepG2 cells, we demonstrate the enhanced predictive power of modules over individual genes in identifying trait associations, particularly in lipid metabolism. By leveraging tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms, PhenoPLIER outperforms traditional single-gene approaches in predicting FDA-approved drug-disease links. The exploration of the phenotype-module space uncovers stable trait clusters associated with relevant tissues, offering valuable insights into the pathogenesis of complex disorders. Overall, PhenoPLIER shifts the paradigm in genetic research by emphasizing the collective behavior of gene groups in specific cell types, thereby enhancing the robustness and interpretability of genetic associations and facilitating the identification of novel therapeutic targets. This innovative approach holds promise for extracting mechanistic insights from genetic data to advance our understanding of complex diseases and therapeutic strategies.
